article:
'Hypothetical types of biochemistry' are forms of
biochemistry speculated to be scientifically viable but not proven to exist at
this time. While the kinds of living beings currently known on Earth commonly
use carbon for basic structural and metabolic functions, water as a solvent and
DNA or RNA to define and control their form, it may be possible that
undiscovered life-forms could exist that differ radically in their basic
structures and biochemistry from that known to science.

The possibility of extraterrestrial life being based on these "alternative"
biochemistries is a common subject in science fiction, but is also discussed in
a non-fiction scientific context.
headings: Chlorine as an alternative to oxygen
Arsenic as an alternative to phosphorus
Selenium or tellurium as an alternative to protein sulfur
Scientists who have considered this topic
